Mattias Fagerlund wrote:

>>That's cool...elaborate, if you would!
>>    
>>
>
>Certainly;
>
>[..]
>
>Anyway, I feed the neural network with the coordinates of each pixel and
>let the network output the shade of that pixel.
>  
>
You mentioned a radius input as well, how does that get used?

This type of visualisation could also be used to analyse network 
functionality by taking any network with two inputs (x and y) from our 
other experiments and drawing it's 2d representation. E.g. if you take 
an XOR network you would expect to see a chequered pattern with 4 
squares - a perfect network would have straight edges, but in reality 
the edges will likely be smooth and curved if you have used a continous 
activation function instead of a step.

Other thoughts:

1) Render color images by using, say, three outputs to describe Red, 
Green, Blue or Hue, Luninence, Saturation. In fact there are loads of 
other color systems, and I guess not all of them use three values.
2) Real-time moving images that represent the changing outputs.
3) Use hidden nodes as the data source. This is a development of the 
anaysis idea - if I have a network with loads of output and hidden 
nodes, I can still visualize the signals being generated on specfic 
nodes by slecting the as a signal source.
3) 3D is harder to imagine, however if you apply a step function to your 
one output value you can potentially use the threshold point to describe 
the surface of a shape, or a more often it would probably be a curved plane.

Combine the lot to get 3D movies of morphing shapes!

Colin
